Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative Research: Genetic Impact of the Deepwater Horizon Oil Release
Award.AbstractNarration:
This RAPID proposal brings together a collaboration among Universities in states affected by the Deepwater Horizon (DH) oil release. With the millions of gallons of oil released, the use of dispersants and the likelihood of movement of the subsurface oil "bloom" into bays and estuaries, an unprecedented anthropogenic impact on human and natural populations may result. This study will define the physiological and evolutionary impact of the DH oil release using the fish Fundulus grandis, a natural inhabitant of estuaries along the Gulf of Mexico. By applying cutting edge technologies, the genetic effects of man's impact on this environment will be described and, thus, provide the baseline data to document the effect of oil pollution on genetic diversity and effectiveness of remediation in limiting negative biodiversity consequences of the spill.

These data will inform society about the short and long-term impacts of the DH oil spill, which has not been possible prior to the recent innovation in genomic techniques. The application of genomic technology provides insights into the genes affected by DH oil and whether cleanup efforts effectively minimize loss of genetic diversity. Thus, this research should provide the evidence of the effectiveness of BP cleanup efforts. Additionally, by measuring the impact of DH oil on fish genomics, additional information will be gathered regarding the genes that matter for human health. Simply put, by measuring the genes in fish that survive exposure to DH oil, genes that may also be important for human health will be identified.

Background:

The release of oil resulting from the blowout of the Deepwater Horizon (DH) drilling platform was one of the largest in history discharging more than 189 million gallons of oil and subject to widespread application of oil dispersants.  Of concern is the release of aromatic hydrocarbons (AH) that could modulate gene expression in fishes through the aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AHR) and the downstream regulation of genes such as the cytochrome P450 (CYP) family of genes.  To assess genomic changes that may lead to biological effects, we quantified mRNA expression using high throughput sequencing technologies (RNA-Seq) to examine representatives of Fundulus grandis populations (a salt marsh minnow) in the marshes and estuaries impacted by DH oil release.

Results:

Comparison of global gene expression patterns in DH oil exposed and unexposed fishes show clear trends in the fish from exposed populations; including the expected AHR-mediated response and CYP genes. In addition several up-regulated genes indicate a response to hypoxic conditions and an immune response. Several genes in the choriogenin family were down-regulated in the exposed group; a response that is consistent with AH exposure. These analyses are in good agreement with oligonucleotide-based microarray analyses, and describe only a subset of significant genes with aberrant regulation in the exposed set.

Conclusion:

RNA-Seq may be successfully applied to feral and extremely polymorphic organisms that do not have an underlying genome sequence assembly to address timely environmental problems. Additionally, the observed changes in a large set of transcript expression levels are indicative of a complex response to the varied petroleum components to which the fish were exposed.
